citation.article-title: Pedobacter roseus sp. nov., isolated from a hypertrophic pond, and emended description of the genus Pedobacter
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pedobacter roseus sp. nov.
Pedobacter roseus (ro.se′us. L. masc. adj. roseus rose-coloured, pink).
Gram-negative, obligately aerobic, short rods, approximately 0.5–0.7 μm wide and 0.8–1.1 μm long.
Cells are non-motile with no flagellum.
Colonies on R2A agar after 2 days are pink and round (1–4.5 mm in diameter), convex and smooth and with entire margins.
Growth occurs between 5 and 33 °C and pH 6 and 8; optimal temperature and pH for growth are 25–30 °C and pH 7, respectively.
Grows well without NaCl, and growth occurs in the presence of up to 2 % (w/v) NaCl.
Grows on R2A medium, nutrient medium, TSA medium and MacConkey's medium.
Positive for catalase, oxidase, gelatinase and amylase activities; negative for heparinase and Voges–Proskauer tests.

Positive for aesculin hydrolysis, gelatinase, acid and alkaline phosphatases, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, valine arylamidase, trypsin, α-chymotrypsin, naphthol-phosphohydrolase, α-galactosidase, α-glucosidase and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase; negative for indole production, glucose fermentation, arginine dihydrolase, urease, lipase (C14), cystine arylamidase, β-glucuronidase, α-fucosidase and α-mannosidase.

Acid is produced from dl-arabinose, d-xylose, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-fructose, d-mannose, methyl α-d-glucopyranoside, amygdalin, aesculin, d-maltose, d-lactose, d-melibiose, sucrose, inulin, d-raffinose, starch, gentiobiose and d-turanose, but not from glycerol, erythritol, d-ribose, l-xylose, d-adonitol, methyl β-d-xylopyranoside, l-sorbose, l-rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, methyl α-d-mannopyranoside, N-acetylglucosamine, arbutin, salicin, d-cellobiose, d-trehalose, d-melezitose, glycogen, xylitol, d-lyxose, d-tagatose, dl-fucose, dl-arabitol, potassium gluconate, potassium 2-ketogluconate or potassium 5-ketogluconate.

Utilizes l-rhamnose, d-cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, glycogen, inulin, d-raffinose, l-xylose, l-glutamic acid, pyruvate, sodium succinate, l-arabinose, trehalose, d-glucose, d-lactose, salicin, sucrose, d-mannose, N-acetylglucosamine and maltose as sole carbon sources, but not l-arginine, ribose, sorbitol, mannitol, gluconate, l-aspartic acid, l-proline, inositol, l-lysine, caprate, adipate, l-malate, citric acid or phenylacetate.

Cells are sensitive to (μg per disc) chloramphenicol (30), ciprofloxacin (5) and tetracycline (30), but resistant to penicillin (10), ampicillin (10), gentamicin (10), kanamycin (30) and vancomycin (30).
The DNA G+C content is 41.3 mol%.
The major isoprenoid is MK-7 and sphingolipids are present.

Fatty acids comprising >1 % of the total are iso-C15 : 0 (37.0 %), iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and/or C16 : 1ω7c (24.5 %), iso-C17 : 0 3-OH (11.3 %), iso-C17 : 1ω9c (7.6 %), iso-C15 : 0 3-OH (2.7 %), anteiso-C15 : 0 (1.9 %), C15 : 1ω6c (1.6 %), unknown ECL (equivalent chain length) 13.565 (1.6 %), unknown ECL 16.582 (1.5 %), C16 : 1ω5c (1.3 %) and iso-C17 : 1 I and/or anteiso-C17 : 1 B (1.1 %).
The type strain, CL-GP80T (=KCCM 42272T=JCM 13399T), was isolated from a hypertrophic pond in Seoul, Korea.
